choices.text: DNA polymerase â†’ protein unwinding enzyme â†’ DNA ligase â†’ DNA Isomerase â†’ Polymerase I
RNA polymerase â†’ DNA polymerase III â†’ DNA polymerase I â†’ DNA ligase
RNA polymerase â†’ DNA polymerase III â†’ DNA ligase â†’ exonuclease â†’ DNA polymerase I
Protein unwinding enzyme â†’ polymerase I â†’ DNA ligase â†’ DNA isomerase â†’ DNA polymerase

questions.text: Which of the following sequences represents the correct order of enzyme activity in DNA replication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA Polymerase â†’ DNA polymerase III â†’ DNA polymerase I â†’ DNA ligase

 

Option B:

 

  • The correct sequence of enzymes includes Helicase, Primase, DNA Polymerase III, DNA Polymerase I and on lagging strand, DNA ligase.

  • Leading strand - Helicase, Primase, DNA Polymerase III

 

Educational Objective:

 

During DNA replication, RNA polymerase (primase) first lays down an RNA primer. DNA polymerase III then extends the DNA strand by adding nucleotides to the primer. DNA polymerase I removes the RNA primer and replaces it with DNA. DNA ligase seals the nicks in the sugar-phosphate backbone, completing the replication process.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 381.

questions.text: In a bacterial genetics study, a particular lethal mutation has been identified that prevents the organism from successfully replicating its chromosome. The affected cells exhibit defective DNA synthesis, characterized by the production of numerous short DNA fragments, each with RNA sequences at their 5' ends. This observation suggests a failure in a critical step of the DNA replication process. Which gene, essential for DNA replication and repair, is most likely affected by this mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA polymerase I

 

Option A:

 

Bacterial DNA polymerase I digests the RNA primers from the 5â€™ ends of the short Okazaki fragments and extends the adjacent fragment into the digested area.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: DNA helicase (Incorrect): They bind to the single-stranded DNA near the replication fork â†’ separates the double strands and keeps them apart. Its deficiency would result in no DNA synthesis.

 

Option C: DNA ligase (Incorrect): If it is defective, it causes accumulation of short pieces consists only of DNA, because this enzyme functions once after the removal of RNA primer.

 

Option D: DNA gyrase (Incorrect): also known as type II topoisomerase which causes transient breaks in DNA supercoils and unwind them, thereby helping in replication. Its deficiency would result in no DNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA polymerase I in bacteria is responsible for removing RNA primers from the Okazaki fragments (short DNA fragments synthesized on the lagging strand during DNA replication) and replacing them with DNA. A defect in DNA polymerase I would lead to the accumulation of short DNA fragments that still contain RNA sequences at their 5' ends, as described in the scenario.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 381-383.

questions.text: DNA is characterized by its unique composition of nitrogenous bases, which are fundamental to its structure and function. Among the options listed below, which base is notably absent in DNA, distinguishing it from RNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Uracil

 

Option B.

 

Uracil is present only in the RNA

 

Nucleic acids are polymers of nucleotides joined by 3'–5' phosphodiester bond.

 

Two Types of Nucleic Acid: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and Ribonucleic acid (RNA).

 

The components of nucleotides are: A nitrogenous base + A pentose Sugar + Phosphate Group

 

Nitrogenous Base: are nitrogen containing heterocyclic ring structures: Purine and Pyrimidine.

 

Purine Bases are Adenine and Guanine

 

Pyrimidine Bases are Cytosine, Uracil and Thymine (Thymine is present only in the DNA)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cytosine: Cytosine is present in both DNA and RNA. In DNA, cytosine pairs with guanine through three hydrogen bonds.

 

Option C. Guanine: Guanine is one of the four main nitrogenous bases found in DNA, where it pairs with cytosine.

 

Option D. Adenine: Adenine is also present in DNA, where it pairs with thymine through two hydrogen bonds. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uracil is the nitrogenous base that is present in RNA but not in DNA. In DNA, thymine is used instead of uracil. This distinction is crucial in differentiating DNA from RNA, both structurally and functionally.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 360.

choices.text: All the strands will have radioactivity
Half of the DNA will have no radioactivity
Threeâ€“fourth of the DNA replicated will have radioactivity

questions.text: In an experiment aimed at understanding DNA replication, a piece of radio-labeled DNA is allowed to undergo two rounds of replication within a non-radioactive medium. This setup is designed to track the distribution of the original radioactive material across the generations of DNA. Based on the known mechanism of semiconservative replication, what would be the expected outcome regarding the radioactivity of the DNA strands after two replication cycles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Half of the DNA will have no radioactivity

 

Explanation:

 

DNA replication follows a semiconservative model, meaning that each daughter DNA molecule retains one original (parental) strand and synthesizes one new strand.

  • After the first round of replication, each of the two daughter DNA molecules contains one radioactive parental strand and one new non-radioactive strand. So, all DNA molecules are partially radioactive.

 

 

  • After the second round of replication, each of these hybrid molecules produces:
    • One hybrid DNA (still containing one radioactive strand)
    • One entirely new DNA molecule (both strands non-radioactive)

 

So now there are four DNA molecules total:

  • Two are hybrid (radioactive + non-radioactive)
  • Two are completely non-radioactive

 

Therefore, half of the DNA molecules (2 out of 4) are non-radioactive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: All strands will have radioactivity â€” Incorrect. Only the original strands are radioactive, and they are passed on to only half of the DNA molecules after two replications.

 

Option B: No strands will have radioactivity â€” Incorrect. The original radioactive strands still exist in two of the four DNA molecules.

 

Option D: Three-fourth of the DNA will have radioactivity â€” Incorrect. Only two out of four DNA molecules (i.e., 50%) retain radioactive material, not 75%.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand the implications of semiconservative DNA replication: in each new round, half of the DNA molecules retain part of the original strand. 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 381-387.

choices.text: To break AT bonds, high Tm is required
To break GC bonds, low Tm is required
To break AT bonds, low Tm is required
AT bonds & GC bonds need same temperature

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing the genetic test results of a child with developmental delays and unusual facial features. The child's DNA analysis indicates a region with a significantly lower melting temperature (Tm) than expected. The pediatrician recalls that DNA regions with varying thermal stability can indicate differences in base pairing, which may be relevant to the child's condition. Which of the following statements best explains the observed low Tm in the child's DNA analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To break AT bonds, low Tm is required.

 

Option C:

 

 

  • When DNA is heated, the temperature at which one half of the helical structure is lost is known as the melting temperature (Tm).
  • The loss of helical structure in DNA is known as denaturation, which can be monitored by measuring its absorbance at 260 nm.
  • As there are three hydrogen bonds between G and C and only two between A and T, DNA which contains high concentrations of A and T denatures at a lower temperature than G, C-rich DNA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This statement is incorrect because AT bonds, having fewer hydrogen bonds, require a lower Tm to break compared to GC bonds.

 

Option B: This statement is incorrect as GC bonds, being more thermally stable due to the presence of an additional hydrogen bond, actually require a higher Tm to break.

 

Option D: This statement is incorrect because AT and GC bonds do not require the same temperature to break due to the difference in the number of hydrogen bonds between them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenine (A) and Thymine (T) base pairs are connected by two hydrogen bonds, whereas Guanine (G) and Cytosine (C) base pairs have three hydrogen bonds. The additional hydrogen bond in GC pairs makes them more thermally stable than AT pairs. Consequently, a lower melting temperature (Tm) is required to separate AT-rich regions of double-stranded DNA compared to GC-rich regions.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e:  p 397

choices.text: It is a semi conservative method
Replication of DNA occurs in 3’ to 5’ direction
The parent DNA strand determines the base sequence of the newly synthesized DNA

questions.text: Which of the following statements about DNA replication is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Replication of DNA occurs in 3’ to 5’ direction

 

Option B:

 

Salient Features of DNA Replication:

 

  • It occurs in the S Phase of the cell cycle.
  • Each DNA Stand separates and acts as template strand on which complementary strand is synthesized on the basis of “Base pairing rule”.
  • Semi conservative model: New Strand is synthesized in the 5’ to 3’ direction and the synthesis of DNA in both strands are not similar. (Option b)
    • Leading strand: DNA is continuously polymerized and Lagging Strand: DNA is discontinuously polymerized (Semi discontinuous).
  • Replication proceeds from multiple origins in each chromosome in eukaryotes and occurs in both directions (bidirectional) in prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
  • Both strands are replicated simultaneously, and the process produces ‘replication bubbles’.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It is a semi-conservative method - This is correct. Each new DNA molecule consists of one original (template) strand and one newly synthesized strand.

 

Option C: It is a semi-discontinuous process - This is correct. The leading strand is synthesized continuously, while the lagging strand is synthesized in short segments called Okazaki fragments, making the overall process semi-discontinuous.

 

Option D: The parent DNA strand determines the base sequence of the newly synthesized DNA - This is correct. The sequence of bases in the parent DNA strand guides the addition of complementary nucleotides to the newly synthesized strand, ensuring accurate replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA replication occurs in a semi-conservative manner, where each new DNA molecule consists of one original strand and one newly synthesized strand. However, the synthesis of the new strand occurs in the 5’ to 3’ direction, not 3’ to 5’. DNA polymerases add nucleotides to the 3' end of the growing strand, necessitating the replication to proceed in the 5’ to 3’ direction.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 381-387.

questions.text: In a discussion on the fidelity of DNA replication in prokaryotes, a group of microbiologists is exploring the various enzymes involved in this process and their specific functions. One key topic is the enzyme responsible for proofreading newly synthesized DNA strands to correct any errors, thus ensuring the accuracy of replication. Which enzyme involved in prokaryotic DNA replication possesses this crucial proofreading activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DNA polymerase II

 

Option C:

 

In prokaryotes, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme responsible for synthesizing new DNA strands during replication. Importantly, it also possesses proofreading activity, thanks to its 3’ to 5’ exonuclease function, which allows it to remove incorrectly incorporated nucleotides and replace them with the correct ones, thereby ensuring high fidelity during DNA replication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: RNA polymerase is involved in transcription, not DNA replication, and does not have proofreading activity associated with DNA synthesis.

 

Option B: Helicase unwinds the DNA double helix to provide single-stranded templates for replication. It does not have enzymatic activity related to nucleotide incorporation or proofreading.

 

Option D: Primase synthesizes RNA primers to provide starting points for DNA polymerase on the lagging strand. It does not have proofreading activity for DNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNAP II has editing and proofreading activity.

 

Prokaryotic DNA Polymerase has 3 types: Pol I, Pol II and Pol III

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 383.

questions.text: A 20-year-old pregnant woman presents with recurrent respiratory infections, night sweats, and unexplained weight loss. Further evaluation confirms tuberculosis and a low white blood cell count. Given her history of multiple sexual partners, she is tested and found to be HIV positive. Alongside antitubercular treatment, her physician recommends starting azidothymidine (AZT) to reduce the risk of maternal-to-fetal HIV transmission. AZT is known to decrease this risk by approximately 30%. What is the primary mechanism of action of AZT in the treatment of HIV?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It inhibits viral reverse transcriptase.

 

Option D:

 

  • The AIDS treatment drug azidothymidine (AZT) inhibits viral reverse transcriptase which is essential for replication of HIV.
  • Reverse transcriptase is an RNA-directed DNA polymerase which synthesizes the HIV- DNA provirus ðŸ¡ªin turn synthesizes new viral RNA.
  • AZT (zidovudine) + non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (e.g., nevirapine) + viral protease inhibitors (e.g., ritonavir) were very effective combination therapies which increases the life span and low fetal transmission rates for AIDS patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It inhibits viral protein synthesis - This is incorrect because AZT's primary action is not on protein synthesis but on the viral DNA synthesis process.

 

Option B: It inhibits RNA synthesis - This is incorrect as AZT specifically targets the reverse transcription process of HIV, which involves the synthesis of DNA from RNA, rather than the synthesis of RNA itself.

 

Option C: It inhibits viral DNA polymerase - This option is partially correct in that reverse transcriptase has DNA polymerase activity, but the more specific and correct description of AZT's target is the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is unique to retroviruses like HIV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azidothymidine (AZT) works by targeting the HIV reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is crucial for converting the viral RNA genome into DNA, a necessary step for viral integration into the host genome and subsequent replication. AZT is a nucleoside analog that, once phosphorylated within the cell, is incorporated into the growing viral DNA chain by reverse transcriptase.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 426.

questions.text: In which phase of the cell cycle does the doubling of DNA occur, a process essential for normal cell division and genetic consistency?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S Phase

 

Option B:

 

Cell cycle:

 

  • The period preceding replication: G1 phase (Gap 1).
  • DNA replication: S (synthesis) phase.
  • Following DNA synthesis, another period (G2 phase or Gap 2) before mitosis(M).
  • Cells that have stopped dividing: G0 phase.
  • Quiescent cells re-enter to resume division: G1 phase.
  • Two key classes of proteins which control the progress of a cell through the cell cycle:  cyclins and cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: G1 phase - This is a period of cell growth and preparation for DNA replication, but DNA doubling does not occur here.

 

Option C: G2 phase - This phase follows DNA replication and involves further cell growth and preparation for mitosis; the DNA has already been replicated in the preceding S phase.

 

Option D: M phase - This phase encompasses mitosis and cytokinesis, where the cell divides its already replicated DNA into two daughter cells. DNA replication does not occur in this phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 381-387.

questions.text: What is the charge of DNA molecules at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Negatively charged

 

Option B.

 

DNA molecules are negatively charged because of the Phosphate group.

 

Histones are proteins which are positively charged at physiological pH due to their high content of lysine and arginine. (option b)

 

Histones along with ions such as Mg2+, neutralize the negatively charged DNA phosphate groups

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Positively charged - This is incorrect because the phosphate groups confer a negative charge to the DNA, not a positive one.

 

Option C. Neutral - DNA is not neutral at physiological pH; the phosphate groups are deprotonated, giving DNA a net negative charge.

 

Option D. Amphipathic - This term describes molecules with both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions. While DNA does have complex interactions with water and proteins due to its structure, the term does not describe its charge; thus, it is not the best answer regarding the charge of DNA at physiological pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At physiological pH (around 7.4), DNA molecules are negatively charged. This is due to the phosphate groups in the DNA backbone, which lose their hydrogen ions and become negatively charged phosphates (POâ‚„³â») at physiological pH. This negative charge is critical for the structure of the DNA double helix and for its interactions with proteins, such as histones, and other molecules within the cell.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 409.

questions.text: Which enzyme is primarily responsible for polymerizing the Okazaki fragments during DNA replication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DNA Polymerase III

 

Option C:

 

  • DNA is synthesized on 5’----> 3’ Strand (Lagging Strand /Retrograde Strand).
  • Synthesized in a discontinuous manner.
  • Small fragments of DNA are 100–250 nucleotides called Okazaki Fragments synthesized in 5’ --- 3’ direction with the help of DNAP III in prokaryotes and DNAP δ in eukaryotes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: DNA Polymerase I: Kornberg’s enzyme from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme, has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities.

 

Option B: DNA Polymerase beta: Involved in proofreading and repair enzyme.

 

Option D: RNA Polymerase I: The DNA polymerase requires a RNA primer which is synthesized by RNA polymerase for initiation of its activity. It is involved in DNA synthesis & Transcription.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In prokaryotic DNA replication, DNA Polymerase III is the enzyme primarily responsible for synthesizing new DNA strands, including the elongation of Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand. It adds nucleotides to the 3' end of the RNA primer of each Okazaki fragment, extending them to complete the replication process.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 381-387.

choices.text: Multiple origins of replication are possible for bacteria
DNA replication proceeds in one direction
Lagging strand stick by RNA primase
DNA polymerase III-processive leading strand synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA polymerase III-processive leading strand synthesis

 

Option D:

 

Salient Features of DNA Replication:

 

  • It occurs in the S Phase of the cell cycle
  • Each DNA Stand separates and acts as template strand on which complementary strand is synthesized on the basis of “Base pairing rule”.
  • Semi conservative model: New Strand is synthesized in the 5’ to 3’ direction and the synthesis of DNA in both strands are not similar.
    • Leading strand: DNA is continuously polymerized and Lagging Strand: DNA is discontinuously polymerized (Semi discontinuous).
  • Replication proceeds from multiple origins in each chromosome only in eukaryotes and occurs in both directions (bidirectional) in prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
  • Both strands are replicated simultaneously and the process produces ‘replication bubbles’.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Multiple origins of replication are possible for bacteria - This statement is false for most bacteria, as bacterial chromosomes, typically being circular, usually have a single origin of replication (oriC in E. coli, for example).

 

Option B: DNA replication proceeds in one direction - This statement is false. DNA replication is bidirectional from the origin, with replication forks moving in opposite directions.

 

Option C: The lagging strand is initiated by RNA primase - While this statement is partially true in that RNA primase lays down RNA primers for Okazaki fragment synthesis on the lagging strand, the statement is phrased in a way that might imply RNA primase alone is responsible for lagging strand synthesis, which is not accurate. DNA polymerase then takes over to extend these primers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA polymerase III is the main enzyme responsible for the synthesis of the leading strand during DNA replication in bacteria.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 381-387.

questions.text: DNA ligase will be required to finish synthesis at which labelled points of the DNA replication fork in the figure.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B and C

 

Option D:

 

  • The areas labelled B and C are lagging strand synthesis in these two replication forks, which shows that the DNA is synthesized in the direction opposite to the direction in which the replication fork is moving.
  • Then DNA must be synthesized in shorts pieces (DNA polymerase can only synthesize DNA in the 5’ to 3’ direction, reading the template in the 3’ to 5’ direction) known as Okazaki fragments.
  • These fragments need to be sealed together by DNA ligase (after the RNA primers have been removed by a DNA polymerase with 5’-3’ exonuclease activity).
  • The vertical line refers to the origin of replication and labels A and D are the leading strands of DNA synthesis, where synthesis occurring in the direction of the replication forks is moving and can be synthesized as one continuous piece of DNA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: A and B - This answer would not typically be correct because one of these points would likely represent the continuous synthesis on the leading strand, which doesn’t require ligase for joining fragments.

 

Option B: C and D - If points C and D represent the lagging strand, then ligase would be needed, but if one represents the leading strand, ligase wouldn’t be required at that point.

 

Option C: A and C - As in option A, this would not typically include two points where ligase is required if one represents the leading strand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA ligase is the enzyme responsible for joining the DNA fragments on the lagging strand during replication. These fragments, known as Okazaki fragments, are synthesized discontinuously and require ligation to form a continuous DNA strand. Based on a typical replication fork, points B and C are positioned to indicate the termination of Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand, where DNA ligase would act to seal the nicks between adjacent fragments.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 390.
